comments.commentBody: Applause, Russian style, for Susan Anderson's performance this evening.
Not sure about your final segue.

EKCO from Eric Kirkham Cole Limited was a British electronics company producing radio and television sets from 1924. Expanding into plastic production for its own use, Ekco Plastics produced both radio cases and later domestic plastic products

We Introduce Knowledge Incessantly

LL, Don't tell me, let me guess, ECKO's first CEO's name was PlastiECKO Domingo?

A penguin walked into a bar and said "Has my father been in here today?"
The bartender said, "I don't know; what does he look like?"

This baby SEAL walks into a bar and the bartender says "What'll you have?"
The SEAL says, "Anything but a Canadian Club..."

A man walked out of the bar and got in his car and a policeman came over.
"Sir, your eyes seem to be bloodshot. Have you been drinking?"
"Officer, your eyes seem to be glazed. Have you been eating doughnuts?"

A pickle walks into a bar and the bartender says, "What are you doing here?"
The pickle replies "Well for starters, I'm celebrating the fact that I can walk."

I got a million of 'em!

WHH

Howie, Bubeleh, We're not about to challenge your assertion that you "Got a million of 'em" but would you be so kind as to space them out, shall we say, over a period of the next ten years, rather than cramming them all in before this week is out?"

Howie hears the collective voices of his Faithful following and will try to accordingly oblige!

Thanks Deb.  Much preferred to listen to Richie Haven than Avenue Q.  Clever theme - of course I didn't see it til I had TINGE.  Several miscues, like a juice for V-8.  Never heard of Marc ECKO, or BREAKING BAR, but I was pleased to know Arp's first name.  Oh, at least I finished.
Martin, That's the world we live in today.  Nobody can be sure.
Plus, I'll admit that references to this couple are like Gitmo to me.  I can't help it.  I'm sure Mia has plenty of issues but I can't imagine her pain.  Eww. Eww. Eww.
I think you meant: "Yes, Evelyn....."

suejean, if you play Deb's clip to the end, you'll see a couple of interviews with Richie Havens; this one shows him with a grey beard, and has Woodstock in the title.

With luck, that will work for you.
Yes, it worked, Leapy, thanks for that.

RubyDear,

RICHIE apparently always wore that necklace. If you search for Mountain Stage and his name, you will find streaming audio of a live set he performed in 1995. The voiceover introducing the tape notes that if you listen carefully, you can sometimes hear the click sounds of his necklace hitting the guitar. If you can't find it, I'll find the link and post it.

Thanks for the memory!

-- MTF

To supplement Deb's information regarding RICHIE Havens:

As to why he ended up being the opening act at the famous music festival:

"The field had been inhabited two days before [Woodstock] was supposed to start," Havens says, "and it sorta clogged itself up on the first day of the concert. No one could get there. So I hear this loud noise in the parking lot out back of the hotel, and it's a glass bubble helicopter. It was a farmer, and he said, 'Sure, I'll take some people over,' and we happened to be the first."

He continues the story here:
http://www.npr.org/2004/08/11/3845549/havens-relives-freedom

So the performance in the video at the end of Deb's blog was entirely improvised!

Havens was a bit under 30 in that video. Early in his career, he had been a poet in Greenwich Village. He was convinced by fellow beatnik poet Allen Ginsberg to get on stage and perform. This eventually encouraged Havens to immerse himself in the folk-music scene and begin a career in music. I suspect it also helps explain his percussive guitar style, because Beats were often accompanied by percussionists when they read their poetry at coffeehouses in the Village. Or so I am told.

My sister met Allen Ginsberg in his older years when she attended a reading of his work. She encountered him outside afterwards, a bit confused as to how to get to his next engagement. She was going that way, so she walked him there.

She had no idea of his earlier career or his cultural significance.

Also, It's easy to find new and popular books at the library now, also classic and new movies and videos. This was a big change. Years ago it took a long time for new books to be available at the library. Also now you can reserve and renew any book in its huge system, vs years ago when you didn't even know what other branches had, unless you pored over big catalog books, or went to that branch. And to reserve, you filled out a postcard which they mailed to you when the book was available.

Today's access to books at the library has advanced by light years. Plus reading reviews on Amazon increases one's exposure to so much. It's like a new world for readers.
So if we get rid of books from our apts, many can still be accessed easily. We need the extra space anyway.

Unfortunately, Meredith, when one moves to a far away place like Maui, one discovers that the libraries are AWFUL. "New and popular books" -- dream on.

Most of the "new and popular books" gracing the shelves my my ramshackle local library were donated to it by ME, after I bought & read them. And only after I have bargained with them to assure that these brand new donated books actually end up on the shelves, instead of in the "books for $1" sale to raise money for this feeble enterprise.

PS - there's only one bookstore on this entire island, and it's over an hour away from where I live.

I moved to a smaller place, and donated many books. Now I do miss a few, alas. I've even borrowed 1 or 2 from the library, to read again. These related to museum shows I saw that rekindled my interest. But other things can restart one's interest and then one misses the book given away.

Piled in cartons are Christie mysteries and Tolstoy's W & P, books on health, music, art, etc. Am I really as interested in them as before? I think I'll reread W&P. Once is not enough.

So this is an ongoing process--I will continue to unload some books in future--as I get older, and as my interests get more defined and focused -- Interests do change at various life stages, some intensify, some weaken.
But I'll always keep Alice in Wonderland, since it relates to our present politics. And Wodehouse which uniquely rings a humor bell in my brain. A nice distraction.

I get my books from the library. When I pass used book sellers on the street, I walk faster to resist browsing.

I just looked at my books on the shelves & realize I may never read many of them. So part of retirement is coming to grips with present reality--it's in flux--what are my current interests, and goals, compared to the past? We've let go of some, or will let go soon, but maybe haven't realized it yet. Time gets shorter! We cling to our old identities even as we change. We live in the past, present and future. The books on our shelves reflect that.

It will be interesting if the rebels (and we don't really know who they are) decide to hold McBrainless for ransom. He might become enlightened in a microsecond.

I remember not too long ago when everyone was rah rahing an invasion of *some* country. I didn't turn so good and the former "owners" have turned over the key, the responsibility, and the blame - to the new "owners." In the biblical "washing of hands" tradition.

Bill Eisen-  I am one of McCain's constituents, and I did not elect him to go to Syria.  I elected him to take care of the people's business, like jobs, etc.  Sure, he has 1st Amendment rights like you and I, but foreign policy stops at our shores.  Beyond that, it's the Presidents call.  McCain can say anything he wants, but doing it while in the midst of Syrian rebels instead of on the Senate floor is unacceptable.
The last time I and my fellow Americans looked Mc Cain and Palin lost pathetically!

Elected officials, including US senators, have the same First Amendment free speech rights as those who post comments to N.Y. Times articles. By going to Syria and expressing his opinions on matters of concern to the American public Senator McCain is doing just what his constituents elected him to do.

President Obama needs to get off his high horse and start listening to his advisers and the American people - most of whom who have advised him to take REASONABLE actions to end the stalemated Syrian war that has cost the lives of thousands of Syrian civilians.

History tell us that the worst kind of action that a country can take is almost always inaction. And right now Obama's inaction is just prolonging Assad's time in power and the misery of the Syrian people.

A lifelong learner and book lover, I moved a year ago, but most of my books did not.
I sold those I could, and dumped trunk loads of others into the bins at the public library. I never imagined it would be so easy. Sometimes I miss one, only to discover that it made the cut after all. No regrets about retirement, but it has a transition period. I love my life, and am still learning, and still reading.

Indeed; most people point the fingers at insurers, which have about 25% overhead including a juicy 3% or so profit (not like the old days, when they could pull in a whopping 5% sometimes); of course, they earn this by bargaining 50-75% off (not a typo; 75% off, not 75% of) nominal medical charges.
Even with that discount, the biggest single chunk of medical costs is physicians' fees; in particular, for secondary or tertiary specialists, rather than your primary care family doctor.
And, oddly enough, payment does not depend on success, either in outcome, or choice of treatment, or even correct diagnosis; which enables insurers to opportunity to cut costs and serve the patient, by preventing medical errors wherever possible.

Jane C,

It's not BREAKING BAR. It's BREAKING BAD, a cable TV show that I believe is about the manufacture and sale of methamphetamine. I have never seen it and do not have Cable TV, but it's one of those shows that get discussed a lot around the water cooler and in the pages of the Times.

For that matter, I don't think I've seen more than five minutes of "Full House", but that wasn't because of lacking TV. It was by choice. Alan THICKE was a common enough media figure, though; and the name of the SEAVER family has pervaded the culture and the puzzle world enough that I was able to get it after some thought.

As for Marc ECKO, if he doesn't design kitchenware, I have no idea who he is either.

-- MissingouTonFrinGE

I opened my own public library.  Taking the cue from a news article several months ago, I built a two-shelved enclosed box that is perched on a secure stand at the edge of the front sidewalk.  I keep it stocked with books.  My neighbors take the books they want and replace them with books they want to share.  I have found that my books on American history aren't taken, the mystery novels are.  DVDs are taken and not returned.   It has been a fun experience for me and I have made new friends in the process.

I have always been a reader, especially of non-fiction. At age 35 I decided to return to school to complete a PhD. The PhD was in an interdisciplinary area, which is in effect like getting multiple PhD's and subsequently, multiple libraries. As I look over my multiple shelves, I see I have a good collection (largely from academic press) in areas as diverse as psychology, geography, history, sociology, philosophy. Add to the my hobbies in art, cooking, photography, writing and I feel like I could open my own public library! Maybe that is what I will do!

I do dread winnowing my books, because I really do connect to them and turn to them. So thanks for the comments, from everyone.
go to www.tinyurl.com. There's a window where you paste a very long url that you want to send to your friends. Click, and they magically give you a short one that you can use instead.
Thanks, 5:30.  I've put that in my notes for when I need it.  Now all I have to do is remember that it's there.

suejeanL, One tries a "tiny url" after the wretched little rotter is apprehended due to running afoul of the law! Heh Heh

'owie
Just went back to read Monday's comments...can't wait to try tiny.url.  Was that Martin's contribution?

Psychopharmacology has immeasurably enriched the practice of psychiatry over the last several decades. The use of medications helps to treat a variety of mental health disorders.

At the same time, mental health problems can simultaneously be addressed successfully with cognitive behavioral therapy, talk therapy and other non-medication-based approaches. That mental health issues can be more difficult to treat than many physical disorders doesn't render psychiatry or psychology meaningless or obscure, it merely means that treatments must be customized, rather than rolled off an assembly line.

To try to reduce mental health issues to a simple set of biological causes is, at least at this stage in our understanding, pseudo-scientific. It's a shame that the critics are trying to dumb down a complex field in which the most effective treatments are typically highly customized to the individual and the circumstances.

"books were incredibly cheap back in 1965"? Strange comment. I remember books being incredibly expensive back in 1965. Perhaps you have neglected inflation. A book you bought in 1965 which has a fading price tag of "$6" on it might seem cheap, but only if you overlook that 6 "1965 dollars" are equivalent to more than 100 "2013 dollars".

I retired from my university teaching position in Japan a couple of years ago, and had to give away about half (or more) of all the books I had accumulated over the decades, before relocating to Hawaii. I thought it would be a big deal, but I regret little, save that I wished I could have donated the books to a really good cause (like a library in Burma, where people would really need and appreciate them). Maybe that's what I'll do with the books I still have, years from now.

Among the "survivors" in my library, I find books that help me recall my youthful intellectual enthusiasms. They invariably have a musty smell and sometimes things fall out of them, like ancient receipts or notes from some person I haven't thought about for a long time. Another thing that strikes me is that books were incredibly cheap back in 1965!

Amen! If you were a medical doctor you would certainly be a good one.
Any psychiatrist who practices responsibly follows what you describe because they are trained in medicine first and then specialize in psychiatry during their residency.. Any psychologist who practices responsibly also considers having their patients having a medical evaluation and assesses that during the initial consultation. The DSM was developed so that communication among professionals contained less surplus meaning and more specificity so that people could communicate what they were treating.
Even with these behaviorally defined criteria professionals do not always agree on diagnoses. Because of that, and because of different treatments that are believed to be effective, the public often maligns the genuine effort to reduce human suffering.

As psychiatrists are physicians they should be providing a medical evaluation. In contrast, psychologists are not and can not be expected to recognize medical illnesses. Thus, it is incorrect to view them as interchangeable.

And, by the way, far more patients with mental disorders are misdiagnosed as having medical disorders than vice-versa.

Neither psychologists nor psychiatrists have the medical expertise and knowledge to perform a metabolic examination.
They should therefore refer their patients to a specialist who can do the evaluation.

I am not a medical doctor.

The following quote is from Chapter 66 of the 8th edition of The Metabolic and Molecular Bases of Inherited Disease.
"There is considerable evidence that many inherited metabolic disorders remain undiagnosed or misdiagnosed. There are a number of reasons the most important of which is the fact that many physicians are not aware of most of the highly specific symptoms or syndromes that are excellent keys to the diagnosis and consequently do not perform comprehensive examinations."

Many metabolic diseases can produce psychological symptoms. While these diseases may be individually rare, collectively they are numerous.
Therefore anyone suffering from psychological problems should undergo a full MEDICAL evaluation and examination.
Many of these errors of metabolism can be treated if properly diagnosed.
A person who can not metabolize phenylalanine will develop normally if put on a phenylalanine restricted diet. A person who can not absorb vitamin B12 or can not form B12 dependent enzymes can be treated with supplemental B12.
My personal opinion is that any psychologist or psychiatrist who treats someone without insisting his patient have a medical evaluation is guilty of malpractice.
Psychology may help some one deal with the symptoms of an untreatable illness but psychology should never be used as the ONLY treatment for an error of metabolism because psychology does not deal with the underlying metabolic cause.

In response to Rick Starr: The US system currently uses an "arms length" standard for transfer pricing. This requires that subsidiaries price their transactions as if the buyer and seller are independent entities.

Neither transaction mentioned in your posting satisfy this rule, and so they would not be legal, even in the current tax regime. Transfer pricing is already important, because taxes on foreign-earned income can be deferred until the profits are repatriated. There is already an advantage to generating income in low tax countries.

I don't see why it makes sense for the taxes paid by a multinational corporation to depend greatly on where it is incorporated, nor why the repatriation of capital should be discouraged. The rest of the world is moving towards territorial taxation. We should, too.

Your piece resonated with me a great deal, as did the comments posted to date. The quandary of letting go and "de-accesssioning", howsoever appropriate it may feel, and how necessary in order to live in a smaller household, nonetheless requires that one come to grips with exactly what you said: that many tasks will not be commenced or concluded, that one will not return to the marginalia or ponder something once thought mysterious or significant.  I think it is healthy and places us in a less ego oriented context, but, candidly, any such relinquishment deprives me of a placeholder, a stimulant for regaining a moment through memory. And that is serious business. Interestingly, I can never predict what will turn out to be particularly potent in terms of making the synapse, so I would urge caution, because the book, or note, or program that winds up discarded or donated may turn out to be a valuable key to enriched experience that connects present to past (to future). Though not there yet, I imagine retirement to be exactly the time to revisit old friends and reestablishing one' s relationship to the ideas of decades past and the colleagues with whom we shared our lives, many of whom live through the texts we might have otherwise tossed.

Make up your mind. What are we: "cheerful pudding" or a " mildly cranky collection" ?

At 72, I'm neither! I'm engaged, active with all ages, but I don't try to convince people that they should love what I love. My biggest surprise about retirement: I don't have time to read all I want!

As I watch my retired friends turn slowly into cheerful puddings, it has become clear that the authorities are going to have to drag me from my college classroom by my hair. I'm delighted to be spending enaged time with young people and not a mildly cranky collection of older people, and I love talking about what I love to a room full of students and convincing them to love it too. I've been teaching for 42 years and the notion of retirement doesn't really interest me. And when I moved to a smaller place, yes, I gave away many boxes of books, and then I lined an entire wall of my garage with many of the rest.

Is there any truth to the rumor that Hans ARP once actually said to Max ERNST, "Who's your Dadaist?"

WHH
Who let the dogs out, "Ruff, Ruff, Ruff, Ruff." Who let the dogs out, "Ruff, Ruff, Ruff, Ruff."

Torts says they went sideways? This team cannot score and are a disaster on the PP. Competed right to the end with Boston? Boston outplayed the Rangers in all five games. There power play was better, they were better shorthanded, 5 on 5, faceoffs, etc. The only thing the Rangers did better was have an amazing goalie. Boston dominated long periods of each game and the number and quality of their scoring chances were absolutely absurd. If Lundquist hadn't been brilliant they would have been swept and the scores would have been ridiculous. Even in the game Lundquist let in 5 goals, he still played well, it's just the Bruins were given countless opportunities to shoot. Let Torts go, find another coach--I'm sure there are plenty of lesser known coaches who know their stuff. We don't need any retreads. We need new blood.

Apparently the NY Times is unaware that Boston Bruin Jaromir Jagr may be the best forward to ever play hockey, and hockey's biggest name. Nor is it aware of the international reputations of Zdeno Chara, Patrice Bergeron, or Brad Marchand. While excusing ignorance of star Bruin forward Milan Lucic, it is difficult to ignore failure to acknowledge national hero and Stanley Cup champion Head Coach Claude Julien.

Perhaps the NY Times is unaware that this Boston Bruins team won the Stanley Cup two years ago. The Bruins roster holds some of the most prominent and most marketable names in hockey. They are a seasoned and celebrated veteran team.

- Hey

Kris,

All goalies wear oversized equipment. Making a connection between equipment size and save percentage to single out one goalie's performance doesn't make sense.

comments.userLocation: Deep in the Heart of NY
comments.commentBody: With all due respect, how many shots could you or I stop with oversized equipment? Even other NHL goalies with his size equipment don't stop as much as he does!

Last I checked, all goalies have size restrictions on their gear. Everything Lundquist is wearing is legal. And the gear don't make the goalie. There are many larger goalies than Lundquist but it's about concentration, reaction, reading the play, knowing player tendencies, and not letting the last puck that went in the net affect you.

Good goalie, but obviously not good enough. I love watching Ranger games to hear the oohs, aahs and "Save Lundqvist!" by the announcers every game whenever he makes a routine save. With all that oversized equipment he wears, he'd better have a great save percentage.

The coach doesn't get the team to the Eastern Conference Finals as he did last year yet somehow considers this season a "sideways step"? No, if the team doesn't get at least as far as they did the year before, then the team did take a step backwards. Seriously, is the sky even blue in Tortorella's world?
